metadata.title: Why Great Stories Fail on Medium and What You Can Do About it? | by Ganes Kesari | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Why Great Stories Fail on Medium and What You Can Do About it?
metadata.description: What makes an article go viral on Medium? Which ones do people actually read? What drives them to click the precious clap button, and when do they fall in love with it? These are questions on the…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: 4 Ways to fail a data scientist job interview
#9-How to flaunt your passion for analytics
What’s the secret sauce to transforming into a unicorn
How grammar of graphics helps craft a great story
Why AI models badly need humans to stay awesome
Simple English explanation of GANs Neural Networks
Why Grammar of Graphics is an ingredient for great Data Stories

all_paragraphs: What makes an article go viral on Medium? Which ones do people actually read? What drives them to click the precious clap button, and when do they fall in love with it?

These are questions on the minds of every writer. We’ll answer them here. We will make the most of the sparse but useful stats that Medium has to offer. We’ll then enrich it with insights from a million Medium stories published over a year, pulled together from public story cards by Harrison Jansma.
This is also a reflection of my year on Medium, highlighting the stories that stood out and identifying some key takeaways on leveling up, as a writer.

While I’ve been blogging for some years, my journey with publications started earlier this year. I’ve published all of my 14 data science articles on TDS, almost on a monthly basis. A huge thanks to the TDS team for building this community and enabling access to such a quality reader base.

My posts target 3 kinds of audience: a) how-to articles to help those aspiring a career in data science, b) explainers that demystify the techniques and methodologies for data science practitioners, c) articles that simplify data science for the non-tech and business audience.

My 14 articles have garnered a total view count of 86,000+ (~120K including RSS views, republications and language translations) and 10,000+ claps. That’s an average of 6000+ views per post with a read ratio of ~40%.

In comparison, Harrison found from his analysis that most Medium articles get fewer than 10 claps, and the top 1% receive more than 2000 claps. That’s about 2700 authors across all of Medium who’ve done that. Consistency is rarer since less than 0.3% of these highly clapped stories have repeat authors.

While my top-viewed story ‘4 Ways to fail a data scientist job interview’ falls in this ballpark, it misses the cutoff for stories tagged data science. So, that’s something to target, along with the consistency.
A number of factors influence the exposure and view count of a story. While the publication’s reach, posting day, time and topic have a say, the clincher is the post title.
“Unless your headline sells your product, you have wasted 90 percent of your money.“ — David Ogilvy

I experiment a fair bit with post titles, but I always dread that final phase of refining the headline before hitting ‘publish’. It’s a frantic analysis paralysis running late into the night, that eats up an hour, and leaves a bad aftertaste.
Here’s what seems to work for my stories, but I’m still learning the ropes here.

The media world has taught us that bad news sells, and titles benefit from a tinge of negativity (‘fail’, ‘frustrate’, ‘struggle’). Listicles work and I use them periodically (‘4 ways’, ‘5 reasons’, ‘3 stages’). Emotional and uncommon words bring in charm and appeal to a drab headline (‘secret’, ‘craze’, ‘real reason’).

While my posts don’t have the volume, the million Medium stories offer some interesting insights in this area. Analyzing articles earning 2000+ claps with tags related to data science, here’s what I found from their titles.
Not surprisingly, most titles had the keywords ‘data science’, ‘AI’, ‘machine learning’, ‘neural networks’, ‘data scientist’. Keeping these aside, we end up with this word cloud:

Most titles are structured as questions ‘how’, ‘why’, ‘what’ and they engage well with users. These posts double up as explainers and use words such as ‘introduction’, ‘understanding’, ‘learn’, ‘guide’, ‘explained’, ‘tutorial’, ‘beginners’.

The listicles stand out and it’s interesting to see the popular numbers: 1–6, 10, 15. They get personal with ’you’, ‘your’, ‘we’, ‘our’. Stories do use negations such as ‘not’, ‘don’t’, ‘zero’, but a sentiment analysis can be more useful here.

Many posts are technical in nature, around ‘python’, ‘pandas’, ‘keras’, ‘jupyter’, ‘tensorflow’, ‘regression’. A good number use personal, emotional or uncommon words such as ‘need to know’, ‘complete’, ‘quick’, ‘free’, ‘new’, ‘big’.

Most stories don’t get any engagement from readers beyond a click. I myself open a few dozen browser tabs every day, and most of them receive no further love until a browser crash puts them to rest forever.
So, which stories manage to achieve this feat? The ‘reads’ count doesn’t tell anything different from the ‘views’ count since both are highly correlated (96% for my limited set).
But, Medium’s Read% is a useful engagement dipstick. I keep an eye out for this, much more than the view count. Here’s how it can uncover hidden gems.

My top story on Data Science interviews has the highest read% (unusually high for a big denominator), but the next 2 are stories with much lower view counts (#9-How to flaunt your passion for analytics and #13-Visualizing machine learning). Despite a low base, they are likely to be read, if picked up.

Every writer has those favorite stories which they felt held a lot of potential, but didn’t get the exposure it deserved. Good stories do fall flat. It could be a poor title, unimpressive thumbnail, wrong timing or a host of other factors.
How does one transcend bias to statistically spot the ones with this hidden potential? The fans conversion ratio (Fans/Reads) is a great proxy here.
Of all people who actually read the story, how many were moved enough to announce it to the whole world (and to the signal hungry algorithms that scour the internet for any and every human activity).
Going by this metric, not one of my top 3 stories made the leaderboard:

The key ones that stand out here are: ‘What’s the secret sauce to transforming into a unicorn’, ‘How grammar of graphics helps craft a great story’, and ‘Why AI models badly need humans to stay awesome’.
It must be noted that the highly viewed stories get exposed well beyond the target audience, so they tend to underperform on this measure.
This is a useful metric for Medium to add to the stats page. Publications and curators can use it to decide which stories must be given a new lease of life.

Having clicked and read a story, it’s a big deal for a user to take time and appreciate it. Not surprisingly, you’d find many posts asking for claps or doing a gif demo on how to do it, though Medium’s curators hate it.
Writers may yearn for it, but a story must rightfully earn it!
A good measure of the love for a story is the count of claps a fan gives it. This is different from the Fans-to-Reads ratio above, which just tells how many of the readers converted into fans.

Now, we set the bar high, since the person needs to hold the button a precious few seconds to drive up the clap count. Those of you who clap 50 times for stories, all the way up until the maximum possible, you’re truly special!

Since Medium cards show just the total claps and not the fan count, I couldn’t run this stat on the million stories (maybe another useful metric for Medium to add?). For mine, the average clap count per fan has been 4.9.

Again, none of my big 5 stories take the top spot here. My post on a ‘Simple English explanation of GANs Neural Networks’ is most loved with 6.62 claps per fan, and a close second is the one on ‘Why Grammar of Graphics is an ingredient for great Data Stories’, with 6.60.

Now finally onto a question that’s been nagging me for long. What’s the right size for a story? Does a long reading time discourage people from clicking? Or, do they skip it when they see the huge scroll within?

Though I’ve been veering towards 1000 words as a benchmark, my stories average 1355 words. I spend time redrafting to make them compact and punchier. I’ve wondered whether to break the really long ones into parts.
To my surprise, long stories aren’t taboo. If anything, it’s been my longer stories that were loved more and had comparable read ratios.
Of my 3 stories with 2000+ words, one is in the top-5 by views, one has a very high reads% and the other is the most loved, with the highest claps/fan ratio.

To be sure, I checked the million Medium dataset and found a +10% correlation between reading time and likes (for the ~200K stories with more than 100 likes). This confirms that users don’t shy away from the long form.
So, if you have a great long story, don’t hold it back.
And, here is an excel with all of my story links and stats, including a few more data than what’s presented here. Can you spot any other interesting nuggets?
Above all, pen stories for the love of writing and to generously share your learnings with the audience. The rest will sort itself out, sooner or later.
And with that, I now hit the publish button and let this story become another statistic :)
Tools used for this article: Excel, R, TableauPublic, and Wordle.net. Thanks to Harrison for the Medium dataset and analysis.
If you found this interesting, you will enjoy these related articles I wrote:
Passionate about data science? Feel free to add me on LinkedIn and subscribe to my Newsletter.
Co-founder & Chief Decision Scientist @Gramener | TEDx Speaker | Contributor to Forbes, Entrepreneur | gkesari.com
